factoid: The narrator says "Hullo, who's there?".
The narrator hears heavy boots and the clinking of spurs.
The narrator hears a respectful cough.
Lavrúshka says "The squadron quartermaster!".
Denísov's face puckers.
Lavrúshka mutters "Wetched!".
Lavrúshka throws down a purse with some gold in it.
Lavrúshka says to Rostóv, "Wostóv, deah fellow, just see how much there is left and shove the purse under the pillow."
Lavrúshka goes out to the quartermaster.
Rostóv takes the money and arranges old and new coins in separate piles.
Rostóv begins counting the coins.
Denísov says "Ah! Telyánin! How d’ye do? They plucked me last night."
A piping voice replies "Where? At Bykov’s, at the rat’s... I knew it."
Lieutenant Telyánin, a small officer of the same squadron, enters the room.
Rostóv thrusts the purse under the pillow.
Rostóv shakes the damp little hand offered to him.
Telyánin had been transferred from the Guards just before this campaign.
Telyánin behaved very well in the regiment.
Telyánin was not liked.
Rostóv detested Telyánin.
Rostóv could not overcome or conceal his groundless antipathy to Telyánin.
Rostóv asks "Well, young cavalryman, how is my Rook behaving?".
Rook is a young horse sold by Telyánin to Rostóv.
Telyánin never looked at Rostóv straight in the face; his eyes continually wandered from one object to another.
Telyánin says "I saw you riding this morning."
Rostóv says "Oh, he's all right, a good horse."
The horse cost seven hundred rubbles, but was not worth half that sum.
Rostóv says "He's begun to go a little lame on the left foreleg."
Rostóv says "The hoof's cracked! That's nothing. I'll teach you what to do and show you what kind of rivet to use."
Rostóv says "Yes, please do."
Rostóv says "I'll show you, I'll show you! It's not a secret. And it's a horse you'll thank me for."
Rostóv says "Then I'll have it brought round."
Rostóv wishes to avoid Telyánin and goes out to give the order.
Denísov, with a pipe, squats on the threshold facing the quartermaster who reports to him.
Denísov sees Rostóv, screws up his face, points over his shoulder with his thumb to the room where Telyánin is sitting, frowns, and gives a shudder of disgust.
Denísov says "Ugh! I don't like that fellow," regardless of the quartermaster's presence.
Rostóv shrugs his shoulders, implying "Nor do I, but what's one to do?".
Rostóv gives his order and returns to Telyánin.
Telyánin sits in the same indolent pose as when Rostóv left him, rubbing his small white hands.
Rostóv thinks "Well there certainly are disgusting people" as he enters.
Telyánin asks "Have you told them to bring the horse?".
Telyánin gets up and looks carelessly about him.
Telyánin says "I have."
Telyánin says "Let us go ourselves. I only came round to ask Denísov about yesterday's order. Have you got it, Denísov?"
Denísov says "Not yet. But where are you off to?"
Telyánin says "I want to teach this young man how to shoe a horse."
They go through the porch and into the stable.
The lieutenant explains how to rivet the hoof and goes away to his own quarters.
When Rostóv goes back there is a bottle of vodka and a sausage on the table.
Denísov sits there scratching with his pen on a sheet of paper.
Denísov looks gloomily at Rostóv's face and says "I am writing to her."
Denísov leans his elbows on the table with his pen in his hand.
Denísov tells Rostóv the contents of his letter.
